div.head: Psal. 55 I. TENOR
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God giue eare and do apply, to heare me whē I pray: and whē to thee I call and cry, hide not thy selfe away. Take heed to mee, ij. graūt my re╌quest, & answere me a╌gaine: with plaints I pray ful sore opprest, great griefe doth me constraine. ij. Beecause my foes with threats & cries, & cries, oppresse me through despite: & so the wicked sort likewise, to vexe me haue de╌light. haue de╌light. For they in coūsell do conspire, ij. to charge me with some ill: So in their hastie wrath, so in their hastie wrath and ire, they do pursue mee still. ij. pursue mee still. they doe pursue mee still. For they &c.

lg.l: MIne eyes with feruencie of sprite,
I doe lift vp on hie:
To thee O Lord that dwel'st in light,
which no man may come nie.
Beehold euen as the seruants eyes,
Vpon their master waite:
And as the maide her mistris hand,
with carefull eye and straite,
Attends: So wee O Lord our God,
thy throne with hope and griefe
Beehold, vntill thou mercie send,
And giue vs some reliefe.
O Lord though wee deserue it not,
yet mercie let vs finde:
A people that despised are,
throwne downe in soule and minde,
The mightie proud men of the world,
that seekes vs to oppresse:
haue fild our soules with all contempts,
and left vs in distresse.

div.head: Psal. 123. II. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MIne eyes with feruencie of sprit, mine eyes with feruencie of sprit, of sprit, with feruencie of sprit, with feruencie of sprit, I doe lift vp on hie: To thee O Lord that dwellest in light, which no man may come nie. may come nie, which no man may come nie.

lg.l: MY soule opprest with care and griefe,
doth cleaue vnto the dust:
O quicken mee after thy word,
for therein doe I trust.
My waies vnto thee haue I shew'd,
thou answerest mee againe:
Teach mee thy law and so I shall,
bee eased of my paine.
The way of thy commaund'ments Lord,
make mee to vnderstand:
And I will muse vpon the power,
and wonders of thy hand.
My heart doth melt and pine away,
for verie paine and griefe:
O, raise mee vp, after thy word,
and send mee some reliefe.
All falsehood, and false waies O Lord,
doe thou from mee remoue:
And graunt mee grace to know thy law,
and onely that to loue.
The way of truth I choose to tread,
to keepe my life in awe:
And set before mee as a marke,
thy sacred woord and law.
I cleaue, O Lord, vnto all things,
witnessed by thy speech:
Whereof that I repent mee not,
I humbly thee beeseech.
When that my heart thou shalt enlarge,
to seeke and runne the waies:
Of thy precepts, I will not faile,
the length of all my daies.

div.head: Psal. 119. III. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Soule opprest with care & griefe, and griefe, with care & griefe, ij. doth cleaue vnto the dust: doth cleaue vnto the dust: O quicken mee after thy word, for therein doe I trust. My wayes vnto thee, my waies vnto thee haue I shew'd, thou answerest me againe: Teach mee thy law and so I shall, & so I shall, be eased of my paine. be eased of my paine, of my paine. Teach me thy law & so I shall, & so I shall, be eased of my paine. ij. be eased of my paine.

lg.l: HOw shall a young man prone to ill,
clense his vnbridled heart?
If that thy law, O Lord hee doe,
all frailtie set apart.
Embrace with setled minde, and learne
thy word with care to keepe:
And search to finde with humble spirit,
thy iudgements that are deepe.
With my whole heart, I haue thee sought,
and searched out thy way:
O suffer not that from thy word,
I swarne or goe astray.
Thy woord O Lord, within my heart,
least I should thee offend:
I haue laid vp as treasure great,
for that shall mee defend.
The Lord is blest, hee shall mee teach,
the iudgements of his mouth,
Thereby to rule and dresse the waies,
of my vntamed youth.
Thy lawes therefore in open place,
my lippes shall euer sound:
And neuer faile to shew forth that,
to which thou hast mee bound.
For in the way of thy precepts,
I set my whole delight:
No wealth, no treasure of the world,
so precious in my sight.
What thou commaund'st I will think on,
With diligent respect:
And to thy lawes haue due regard,
for they shall mee protect.
In thy precepts O Lord, my soule
her whole delight hath set:
Thy words therefore more pure then gold,
I neuer will forget.

div.head: Psal. 119. IIII. 〈◊〉
div.p:
〈♫〉
HOw shal a yong man prone to ill, clense his vnbridled hart, vnbridled heart, vnbridled hart? If that thy law O Lord he doe, all frailtie set apart. Embrace, embrace with set╌led mind, ij. with setled minde, and learne thy word with care to keepe, with care to keepe, to keepe. And seeke to finde with humble sprite, thy iudgements that are deep. that are deep, thy iudgements that are deep, are deepe, thy iudgements that are deepe. And seeke to finde with humble sprite, and seeke to finde with humble sprite, thy iudgements that are deep. that are deep, thy iudgements that are deepe. are deepe. thy iudgements that are deepe.

lg.l: O Lord, how long wilt thou forget,
to send mee some reliefe,
For euer wilt thou hide thy face,
and so increase my griefe?
How long shall I with vexed heart,
seeke counsell in my spirit?
How long shall my malicious foes,
triumph and mee despite?
O Lord my God, heare my complaint,
vttered with wofull breath:
Lighten mine eyes, defend my lyfe,
that I sleep not in death.
Least that mine enemie say, I haue
against him loe preuayl'd:
At my downefall they will reioyce,
that thus haue mee assayl'd.
But in thy mercie Lord I trust,
for that shall mee defend:
My heart doth ioye, to see the help,
which thou to mee wilt send.
Vnto the Lord therefore I sing,
and doe lift vp my voyce:
And for his goodnesse shew'd to mee,
I will alway reioyce.

div.head: Psal. 13. V. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord, how long wilt thou forget, how long wilt thou forget, O Lord, how long wilt thou forget, to send mee some re╌liefe? For euer wilt thou hide thy face, and so increase my griefe? How long shall I, shall I, with vexed hart, seeke counsell in my sprite, seeke counsell in my sprite? How long shall my ma╌li╌cious foes, tri╌umph & me despite? despite? How long shall my mali╌ci╌ous foes, ma╌li╌cious foes, tri╌umph and mee despite? triumph and mee despite? triumph and mee despite?

lg.l: O Lord who in thy sacred tent,
and holy hill shall dwell:
Euen he that both in heart and mind,
doth studie to doe well.
In life vpright, in dealing iust,
and he that from his heart
The truth doth speake with singlenes,
all falsehood set apart.
With tongue besids that hurts no man,
by false and ill report:
Nor friend nor neighbour harme will doe,
where euer hee resort.
That hates the bad, and loues the good,
and faith that neuer breakes:
But keeps alwaies though to his losse,
the woord that ones he speakes.
Nor filthie gaine by loue that seekes,
nor wealth so to possesse:
Nor that for bribes, the guiltles soule,
doth labour to oppresse.
Like as a mount so shall he stand,
nothing shall him remoue:
That thus shall doe, the Lord hath said,
no man can it disproue.

div.head: Psal. 15. VI. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord, O Lord, who in thy sacred tent, O Lord, O Lord who in thy sacred tent & holy hill shal dwell, shall dwel: Euen hee that both in hart and mind, doth studie to doe well doth studie to do well. In life vpright, in dealing iust, in dealing iust, & he that from his hart, from his hart, the truth doth speak, with single╌nesse, with single╌nes, the truth doth speake, with singlenesse, all falshod set apart. the truth doth speake, with single╌nesse, all falsehood set apart. all falshood set apart. set a╌part.

lg.l: HElp Lord for wasted are those men,
which right'usnesse embrace:
And rarely found that faithfull are,
but all the truth deface.
Each to his neighbour falsehood speakes.
and them seekes to beguile:
With flattering lips and double heart,
when smothest hee doth smile.
All flattering lips, the Lord our God,
in iustice will confound:
And all proud tongues, that vaunt great things,
hee will bring to the ground.
Our tongues say they, shall lift vs vp,
by them wee shall preuaile:
Who should vs let, or stop our course,
that thereof wee should faile.
For the destruction of the iust,
and such as bee opprest:
And for the mournings of the poore,
that likewise bee distrest.
I will ryse vp now saith the Lord,
and ease their griefe and care:
Of those which hee full craftely,
hath draw'n into his snare.
Like siluer fine that tried is,
seuen times by heate of fire:
So are thy words Lord pure and cleane,
to such as them desire.
Thou Lord wilt keepe, and wilt defend,
all such as in thee trust:
And from that cursed race of men,
saue all such as bee iust.
When euill men exalted bee,
the wicked gad about:
Farre from all feare of paine, but thou
O Lord wilt roote them out.

div.head: Psal. 12 VII. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HElp Lord for wasted are those men, which right'usnes embrace: Help Lord for wasted are those men, which right'usnes embrace: And rarely found that faithfull are, but all the truth de╌face. Each to his neighbor falsehood speakes, each to his neighbour falshod speakes, and thē seeks to bee╌guile: beeguile: With flat'ring lips, and dou╌ble heart, when smothest hee doth smile. With flat'ring lips, with flat'ring lips, & dou╌ble heart, when smothest hee doth smile. ij. hee doth smile

lg.l: BLessed is hee that feares the Lord,
hee walketh in his waies:
And sets his great delight therein,
the length of all his daies.
His seede and those which of him come,
mightie on earth shall bee:
The race of such as faithfull are,
men blessed shall them see.
Plenteousnesse within his house,
and want there shalbe neuer:
His righteous and vpright dealing,
dure shall for euer.
In mistie clouds of troubles dark,
which doe the iust oppresse:
The Lord in mercie sends them light,
and easeth their distresse.
The righteous man is mercifull,
and lendeth where is neede:
Hee guides with iudgement all his things,
be it in word or deede.
Though stormes doe fall and tempests rise,
the righteous shall stand fast:
A good remembrance of the iust,
for euer that shall last.
None euill tidings shall him feare,
his heart is fully set:
Hee trusteth and beleeues the Lord,
that will him not forget.
A stablished heart within his brest,
no feare where so hee goes:
The Lord in iustice will reuenge,
the mallice of his foes.
A hand that doth relieue the poore,
for which hee may bee sure:
A good report will follow him,
that alwaies shall endure.
This shall the wicked see and fret,
and wast away with ire:
Perish shall and consume to naught,
all that hee doth desire.

div.head: Psal. 112. VIII. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BLessed is hee that fears the Lord, that fears the Lord, he walketh in his waies, in his waies, hee walketh in his waies, his waies: and sets his great delight there╌in, the length of all his daies. His seede and those which of him come, which of him come, mightie on earth shall bee: The race of such as faithful are, men blessed shal thē see. ij. men blessed shall them see. The race of such as faithfull are, men blessed shall them see. men blessed shall them see. men bessed shall them see

div.head: Psal. 6. IX. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 LOrd in thy wrath reproue mee not, though I deserue thine yre: deserue thine yre: Ne yet correct mee in thy rage, O Lord I thee desire. ij. For I am weak, therefore (O Lord) of mercie mee forbeare: & heale mee Lord, for why? thou know'st, ij. my bons do quake for fear my bons do quake for fear.

div.head: X.
div.p: 〈♫〉 EVen from the depth, vnto thee Lord, from the depth vnto thee Lord, vnto thee Lord, vnto thee Lord, thee Lord, with heart and voice I crie: ij. Giue eare O God vnto my plaint, and helpe my mi╌sery. ij. and help my mi╌se╌ry.
div.trailer: ¶ Here endeth the Psalmes, and followeth the Sonets and Pastorales.

div.head: XI. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Ioy not in no earthly blisse, I force not Cressus welth a straw: For care I know not what it is, I feare not Fortunes fa╌tall law. My minde is such as may not moue, ij. for beautie bright nor force of loue. force of loue. My minde is such as may not moue, ij. for beautie bright nor force of loue. force of loue.

lg.l: I wish but what I haue at will,
I wander not to seeke for more:
I like the plaine I clime no hill,
in greatest stormes I sit on shore:
and laugh at them that toyle in vaine,
to get what must bee lost againe.
I kisse not where I wish to kill,
I faine not loue where most I hate:
I breake no sleepe to winne my will,
I waite not at the mighties gate:
I scorne no poore nor feare no rich.
I feele no want nor haue to much.
The Court and cart I like nor loath,
extreames are counted worst of all:
the golden meane beetweene them both,
doth surest sit and feare no fall:
this is my choyce, for why I finde,
no wealth is like the quiet minde.

div.head: XII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 THough Amarillis daūce in green, daūce in greene, like Fay╌rie Queene, & sing full cleer, Cori╌na can with smiling cheer, with smiling cheer, ij. yet since their eies make hart so sore, hey ho, chill loue, no more. ij. no more. hey ho chil loue no more. chil loue no more. no more. chil loue no more. no more. hey ho chil loue no more. ij. no more. hey ho, chil loue no more, ij. chil loue no more. chil loue no more.

lg.l: My sheepe are lost for want of food,
and I so wood:
that all the day,
I sit and watch a heardmaid gaye:
who laughes to see mee sigh so sore,
hey ho, chill loue no more.
Her louing lookes, her beautie bright,
is such delight:
that all in vaine,
I loue to like, and lose my gaine:
for her that thanks mee not therefore,
hey ho, chill loue no more.
Ah wanton eyes my friendly foes,
and cause of woes:
your sweet desire,
breedes flames of Ise and freese in fire:
yee skorne to see mee weep so sore,
hey ho, chill loue no more.
Loue yee who list I force him not,
sith God it wot,
the more I wayle,
the lesse my sighes and teares preuaile,
what shall I doe but say therefore,
hey ho, chill loue no more.

div.head: XIII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 WHo likes to loue let him take heed, ij. and wot you why: and wot you why: ij. and wot you why: ij. Among the Gods it is decreed, that Loue shall die. ij. that Loue shall die. And euerie wight that takes his part, ij. his part, shall forfaite each, a mourning heart. a mourning heart. and euery wight that takes his part, that takes his part, shall forfaite each a mourning heart. a mourning heart. ij.

lg.l: The cause is this as I haue heard,
a sort of dames,
whose beautie he did not regard,
nor secret flames,
complaind before the gods aboue,
that gold corrupts the God of Loue.
The gods did storm to heare this newes,
and there they swore,
that sith hee did such dames abuse,
hee should no more
bee god of Loue, but that hee should.
both dye, and forfait all his gold.
His bow and shafts they tooke away,
beefore their eies,
and gaue these dames a longer day,
for to deuise,
who should them keepe, and they bee bound,
that loue for gold should not bee found.
These Ladies striuing long, at last
they dyd agree,
to giue them to a maiden chast,
whome I dyd see:
who with the same did perce my brest,
her beauties rare and so I rest.

div.head: XIIII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 MY minde to me a kingdome is, such perfect, ioy therin I find: That it excels all other blisse, all other blisse, that God or Nature hath assign'd. hath assign'd. hath assign'd. Though much I want, thogh much I want, that most wold haue, yet still my mind, forbids to craue. to craue. Though much I want, that most wold haue, though much I want, though much I want, that most would haue, yet still my minde, forbids to craue. to craue. to craue. forbids to craue.

lg.l: No princely port nor welthie store,
no force to winne a victorie.
no wyly wit to salue a sore,
no shape to winne a louing eye:
to none of these I yeld as thrall,
for why my minde despise them all.
I see that plentie surfets oft,
and hastie clymbers soonest fall:
I see that such as are a loft,
mishap doth threaten most of all:
these get with toyle and keepe with feare,
such cares my minde can neuer beare.
I presse to beare no haughtie sway,
I wish no more then may suffice;
I doe no more then well I may,
looke what I want my minde supplies,
loe thus I triumph like a King,
my minde content with any thing.
I laugh not at a nothers losse,
nor grudge not at anothers gaine:
no worldly waues my minde can tosse,
I brooke that is an others bane:
I feare no foe nor fawne on friend,
I loth not lyfe nor dread mine end.
My wealth is health and perfect ease,
and conscience cleere my chiefe defence,
I neuer seeke by brybes to please,
nor by desert to giue offence:
thus doe I liue, thus will I dye,
would all did so as well as I.

div.head: XV. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 WHer fancie fond for pleasure pleads, ij. wher fancie fond for plesure pleads, and reason keeps poore hope in Iayle: poore hope in Iayle: Ther time it is to take my beads, to take my beads, & pray, & pray, that beautie may preuaile: or else dispaire, ij. will win the field, the field, wher reason, hope, and pleasure yeeld: & pleasure yeeld. or else dispaire, ij. wil win the field: the field: wher reason, hope, & pleasure yeeld. and pleasure yeeld.

lg.l: My eyes presume to iudge this case,
whose iudgement reason doth disdaine:
but beautie with her wanton face,
stands to defend, the case is plaine:
and at the barre of sweet delight,
she pleads that fancie must be right.
But shame will not haue reason yeeld,
though griefe doe sweare it shall be so:
as though it were a perfect shield,
to blush and feare to tell my woe:
where silence force will at the last,
to wish for wit when hope is past.
So farre hath fond desire out runne,
the bond which reason set out first:
that where delight the fray begun,
I would now say if that I durst:
that in her steed ten thousand woes,
haue sprong in field where pleasure growes.
O that I might declare the rest,
of all the toies which fancie turnes:
like towres of winde within my brest,
where fire is hid that neuer burnes,
then should I try one of the twaine,
either to loue, or to disdaine.
But since conceit dares not declare,
the strange conflict of hope and feare:
least reason should be left so bare,
that loue durst whisper in mine eare,
and tell mee how my fancie shall,
bring reason to be beauties thrall.
I must therefore with silence build,
the Laborinth of my delight:
till Loue haue try'd in open field,
which of the twaine shall win the sight:
I feare mee reason must giue place,
If fancie fond win beauties grace.

div.head: XVI. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 O You, that heare this voice, O you that see this face, this face, say whether of this choice, may haue the former place: Who dare iudge this de╌bate, ij. that it bee voide of hate. ij. This side doth beautie take, for that doth Musicke speak, ij. fit Orators to make: the strongest iudgements weak. ij. The bar to plead their right, is onely true de╌light. ij. is onely true de╌light. The bar to plead their right, is onely true de╌light. is onely true delight. is onely true de╌light.

lg.l: Thus doth the voyce and face,
these gentle lawiers wage:
like louing brothers cast,
for fathers heritage:
that each, while each contends,
it selfe to other lends.
For beautie beutifies,
with heauenly hew and grace,
the heauenly harmonies,
and in that faultlesse face,
the perfect beauties bee,
a perfect harmonie.
Musicke more loftie swells,
in phrases finely plac'd:
Beautie as farre excells,
in action aptly grac'd:
a friend each partie drawes,
to countenance his cause.
Loue more affected seemes,
to beauties louely light,
and wonder more esteemes,
of Musick wond'rous might,
but both to both so bent,
as both in both are spent.
Musicke doth witnesse call,
the eare his truth doth trye:
Beautie brings to the hall,
eye witnesse of the eye,
each in his obiect such,
as none exceptions touch.
The cōmon sense which might,
bee arbiter of this:
to bee forsooth vpright,
to both sides parciall is:
hee layes on this chiefe praise,
chiefe praise on that hee laies.
Then Reason, princesse hie,
which sits in throne of minde:
and Musicke can in Skye,
with hidden beauties finde,
say whether thou wilt crowne,
with limit lesse renowne.

div.head: XVII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 IF women could be faire & neuer fond, if women could be faire, & neuer sond, or that their beauties might con╌tinue still: I would not meruaile though they made men bond, though they made, though they made men bōd, by seruice long, to purchase their good will. by seruice long to purchase their good will. But when I see, how frail, these cretures are, I laugh, that men forget themselues so far. so far. But when I see, how fraile, these creatures are, these creatures are, I laugh, that men for get themselues so farre. so farre. forget themselues so farre. so farre.

lg.l: To marke what choise they make, and how they chāge
how leuing best the worst they chose out stil:
And how like haggards wilde, about they range,
Skorning after reason to follow will.
Who would not shake such bussards from the fist,
& let them flie (faire fooles) which way they list.
Yet for our sport, wee fawne and flatter both,
To passe the time, when nothing else can please:
And traine them on to yeeld by subtill oath,
The sweet content, that giues such humor ease.
And then wee say, when wee their follies trie,
To play with fooles, Oh what a foole was I.

div.head: XVIII. TENOR
div.p: 〈♫〉 AMbitious loue hath forst me to aspire, the beauties rare which do adorne thy face: Thy modest life yet bridles my de╌sire, whose seuere law doth promise mee no grace. doth promise mee no grace. But what? may loue liue vnder any law? No, no? his power exceedeth mans conceit: Of which ye Gods thēselues do stand in awe, for on his frown, a thousand tormēts waite. ij. Proceed then in this desperate enterprise, with good aduise, aduise, & follow, loue thy guide, that leads thee to, that leads thee to thy wished Paradise, to thy wished Paradise. Thy climing thoughts, this comfort take with all, that if it bee, it bee thy foule disgrace to slide, thy braue attempt, ij. shall yet excuse thy fall. ij. thy fall.

div.head: XIX. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WHat pleasure haue great princes, haue great princes, what pleasure haue great princes, more daintie to their choice, to their choice, then heardmen wild, who carelesse, in quiet life reioyce: & fortunes fate not fearing, not fea╌ring, sing sweet, in Sommer, sing sweet in Sommer morning. and fortunes fait not fearing, not fea╌ring, sing sweet, in Sommer, sing sweet in Sommer morning.

lg.l: Their dealings plaine and rightfull,
are voyde of all disceit:
they neuer know how spightfull,
it is to kneele and waite
on fauorite presumptious,
whose pride is vaine and sumptious.
All day their flocks each tendeth,
at night they take their rest,
more quiet than who sendeth
his ship into the East,
where gold and pearle are plentie,
but getting very daintie.
For Lawiers and their pleading,
the'steeme it not a straw,
they think that honest meaning
is of it selfe a law,
where conscience iudgeth plainely,
they spend no mony vainely.
O happie who thus liueth,
not caring much for gold,
with clothing which suffiseth,
too keepe him from the cold,
though poore and plaine his diet,
yet merrie it is and quiet.

div.head: XX. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉 AS I beheld, I saw a heardman wild, I saw a heardman wild, with his sheephook a picture fine deface, with his sheephooke a picture fine deface, de╌face, which he somtime his fancie to beguile, had caru'd on barke of beech, in secret place, & with despite of most afflicted minde, of most afflicted mind, through deepe dispaire of hart, for loue dis╌maid, through deepe dispaire of hart, for loue dismaid, he puld euen from the tree, the carued rinde, the carued rinde, the car╌ued rinde, and weping sore these wofull words, he said: & weeping sore these wofull words, he said: he said: hee said: ah Philida, Philida, ah Philida, would God thy picture faire, I could as lightly blot out of my brest, then should I not thus rage, with great despight, despight,
& teare the thing sometime I liked best, sometime I li╌ked best, but all in vaine, ij. but all in vaine, it booteth not god wot, it booteth not god wot, god wot, what printed is in hart, ij. on tree to blot. ij. but all in vaine, but all in vaine, it booteth not god wot, it booteth not god wot, god wot, what printed is in hart, ij. on tree to blot. ij. on tree to blot.

div.head: XXI.
div.p: 〈♫〉 ALthough the heathen poets did Appollo famous praise, as one who for his Musicke sweet, his Musicke sweet, no peere, had in his daies in his daies. no peere had in his daies. Although the heathen poets did, poets did. Although the, &c.

div.head: XXII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 IN fields abroad, wher Trumpets shrill doe sound, ij. wher glaues & shields, do giue & take the knocks, wher bodies dead, do ouerspred the ground, & friend to foes, to foes, are common butchers blocks: A gallant shot, ij. a gallant shot well managing his peece, well managing his peece, in my conceit, ij. conceit, deserues, deserues a golden fleece. deserues a golden fleece. a golden fleece. A gallant shot, ij. a gallant shot, well managing his peece, well managing his peece, in my conceit, ij. conceite, deserues, deserues a golden fleece. deserues a golden fleece. a golden fleece.

div.head: XXIII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 COnstant Penelope, Penelo╌pe, sends to thee carelesse Vlisses, write not againe, but come sweet mate thy selfe to reuiue mee. Troy wee doe much enuie, ij. wee desolate lost Ladies of Greece. Not Priamus, nor yet all Troy can vs recompēce make. Oh, oh, oh, that hee had when hee first tooke shipping to Lacedemon, to Lacede╌mon, that adulter I meane, had beene o'rewhelmed with wa╌ters: Thē had I not lien now all a╌lone, thus quiuering for cold, nor v╌sed this complaint, complaint, nor haue thought the day to bee so long. Then had I not lien now all a╌lone, thus quiuering for cold, nor v╌sed this complaint, complaint, nor haue thought the day to bee so long.

div.head: XXIIII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 LA virginella ij. è simil' alla ro╌sa, ch'in bel giardin sula natiua spi╌na, Mentre sola è sicura Mentre sola si ripo╌sa, Ne gregge, ne pastor se le auicina: L'aura soaue, ij. & Palba rugia dosa, rugia dosa, L'acqua, la terra, al s'uo fauor s'inchina, ij. s'inchina: Giouani va╌ghi, ij. e donn' inamora╌te, ij. Amano hauerne è seni e tempie or╌na te. Gioua╌ni vaghi, ij. e donn'in╌amora te. ij. Amano hauerne e seni e tempie orna╌te.

div.head: XXV. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 FArewell false loue the o╌ra╌cle of lies, farewell false loue, the o╌ra╌cle of lies, a mortall foe, a mortall foe, and eni╌mie to rest: An enuious boye, an enuious boy, from whom all cares arise, from whom all cares a╌rise, A bastard vile, a bastard vile, a beast with rage pos╌sest: A way of error, of error, a temple full of treason, in all effects, contrarie vnto reason. A way of error, of error, a temple full of treason, in all effects, contrarie vnto reason.

lg.l: A poisoned serpent couered all with flowers,
Mother of sighes, and murtherer of repose,
A sea of sorows frō whēce are drawē such flowers,
As moisture lend to euery griefe that growes,
A schole of guile, a net of deepe deceit,
A guilded hooke that holds a poisoned baite.
A fortresse foyld which reason dyd defend,
A Syren song, a feauer of the minde,
A maze wherein affection findes no ende,
A raging cloud that runnes before the winde,
A substance like the shadow of the Sunne,
A goale of griefe, for which the wisest runne.
A quenchlesse fire, a nursse of trembling feare,
A path that leades to perill and mishap,
A true retreat of sorrow and dispaire,
An idle boy that sleepes in pleasures lap,
A deepe mistrust of that which certaine seemes,
A hope of that which reason doubtfull deemes

div.head: XXVI. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 THE match that's made for iust & true re╌spects, for iust & true respects, for iust & true respects, & true respects: with euennes both of yeers & parentage, & parentage, ij. of force must bring forth ma╌ny good effects. of force must bring foorth many good effects. of force must bring forth many good effects. many good ef╌fects. Pa╌ri iugo dul╌cis trac╌tus. Pari iu go dulcis trac╌tus. ij. trac╌tus. dulcis trac╌tus.

lg.l: For where chast loue and liking sets the plant,
And concord waters with a firme good will,
Of no good thing ther can be any want.
Sound is the knot that chastitie hath tyde,
Sweet is the Musicke vnitie doth make,
Sure is the store that plentie doth prouide.
Where chastnesse fayles, ther concord wil decay,
Wher concord fleets, ther plentie will decrease,
Wher plentie wants, ther loue will weare away.
I chastitie restraine all strange desires,
I Concord keep the course of sound consent,
I Plentie spare, and spend as cause requires.
Make much of vs, all yee that married bee,
Speake well of vs, all yee that minde to bee,
The time may come to want and wish all three.

div.trailer: Heere endeth the Sonets and Pastoralls, and followeth Songs of sadnesse and pietie.

div.head: XXVII. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PRostrate O Lord, I lie, I lie, Prostrate O Lord, I lie, ij. I lie, behold, mee Lord, with pittie, stop not thine eares against my cry, my sad and mourning dittie. Breath'd frō an in╌ward soule, an inward soule, from hart hartely contrite, an offering sweet, an offering sweet, a sacrifice, in thy high heauen╌lie sight. high heauenly sight. in thy high heauenlie sight.

lg.l: Obserue not sinnes O Lord,
for who may then abide it,
but let thy mercie cancell them,
thou hast not man dem'd it,
man melting with remorse and thoughts,
thought past repenting,
O lighten Lord, O heare our songs,
our sinnes full sore lamenting.
The wonders of thy works,
aboue all reason reacheth,
and yet thy mercie aboue all
this, vs thy spirit teacheth,
then let no sinner fall,
in depth of foule dispaire,
since neuer soule so foule there was,
but mercie made it faire.

div.head: XXVIII. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
AL as a Sea, the world no other is, no other is, no other is, our selues are ships still tossed too & fro, and loe, each man, his loue to that or this, his loue to that or this, is like a storme, that driues the ship to goe: that thus our life in doubt of shipwrack stands, of shipwrack stands: our wils the rockes, our want of skill the sands. the sands. that thus our life in doubt of shipwrack stands, of shipwrack stands: our wils the rockes, our want of skil the sands. the sands.

lg.l: Our passions be Pirates still that spoyle,
and ouerboard cast's out our reasons fraight:
the Marriners that day and night doe toyle,
bee our conceits that doe on pleasure waight:
pleasure Master doth tirannize the Ship,
and giueth Vertue secretly the nip.
The compasse is a minde to compasse all,
both pleasure, profit, place and fame, for naught:
the windes that blow men ouerweening call,
the Merchandise is wit full deerely bought:
tryal the' Anker cast vpon experience,
for labor, lyfe, and all a doe the recompence.

div.head: XXIX. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SVsan╌na faire, sometime assaulted was, Susanna assaulted was, by two, by two old men, desiring their delight: whose false intent, ij. they thought to bring, to passe, to bring to passe, by force and might: to whom she said, if I your sute de╌nie, you will me falsely accuse, & make mee die. & make mee die. mee die. To whom she said if I your sute de╌ny, you wil mee falsely ac╌cuse, and make mee dye. and make mee die. mee die.

lg.l: And if I graunt to that which you request,
my chastitie shall then defloured bee,
which is so deere to mee that I detest
my lyfe, if it beerested bee from mee:
And rather would I dye of mine accord,
ten thousand times, then once offend the Lord.

div.head: XXX. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
IF that a sinners sighes, ij. be Angels food, or that repentaunt teares be Angels wine, Angels wine, be Angels wine, accept O Lord, ij. in this most pensiue moode, most pensiue mood, these hartie sighes, ij. and faith╌full teares of mine: That went with Pe╌ter forth most sinfullie, most sinfullie, sin╌fullie, but not with Peter wept, most bitterlie. That went with Pe╌ter foorth, most sinfullie, most sinfullie, sin╌fullie, but not with Peter wept, most bitterlie. most bitterlie.

lg.l: If I had Dauids Crowne to mee beetide,
or all his purple robes that hee did weare,
I would lay then such honor all aside,
and onely seeke a sackcloth weede to beare,
his Pallace would I leaue that I might show,
and mourne in cell for such offence, my woe.
Ther should these hands beat on my pensiue brest
and sad to death, for sorrow rend my haire,
my voice to call on thee, should neuer rest,
whose grace I seeke, whose iudgement I doe feare:
vpon the ground all groueling on my face,
I would beseech thy fauour and good grace.
But since I haue not meane to make the show
of my repentaunt minde, and yet I see
my sinne to greater heape than Peters grow,
wherby the daunger more it is to mee,
I put my trust in his most precious bloud,
whose life was paid to purchase all our good.
Thy mercie greater is then any sinne,
thy greatnesse none can euer comprehend:
wherefore O Lord, let mee thy mercie winne,
whose glorious name no time can euer end:
wherefore I say all prayse belongs to thee,
whom I beseech bee mercifull to mee.

div.head: XXXI. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 CAre for thy soule as thing of greatest price, care for thy soule, for thy soule, as thing of grea╌test price, made to the ende to tast of power deuine, of power deuine, de╌uine, deuoide of guilt, abhorring sinne and vice, apt by Gods grace to vertue to encline, to encline, care for it so, as by thy retchlesse traine, it bee not brought to tast, eternall paine. care for it so, as by thy retchlesse traine, it bee not brought to tast, eternall paine

lg.l: Care for thy corps, but chiefly for souls sake
cut of excesse, sustaining food is best,
to vanquish pride, but comely clothing take,
seeke after skill, deep ignorance detest:
Care so I say, the flesh to feed and cloth,
that thou harme not thy soule & body both.
Care for the world to doe thy body right,
rack not thy wit to win by wicked waies,
seeke not t'oppresse the weak by wrongfull might,
to pay thy due doe banish all delaies:
Care to dispend according to thy store,
and in like sort be mindfull of the poore.
Care for thy soule, as for thy chiefest stay,
care for thy bodie for the soules auaile,
care for the world for bodies help alway,
care yet but so as vertue may preuaile,
care in such sort that thou be sure of this,
care keep thee not frō heauen & heauēly blis.

div.head: XXXII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 LVlla, lul╌la, lul╌la, lulla╌by, Lulla, lul╌la╌by, la lulla, lullaby, my sweet little, little ba╌by, my sweet little baby, what meanest thou to crye, Lulla, lulla╌by, lulla╌by, by, la lul╌la╌by, la lulla la lul╌la╌by, la lulla, lul╌la╌by, lul╌la╌by, my sweet little baby. ba╌by.

div.head: The second part.
div.p:
〈♫〉 BEe still my blessed babe, blessed babe, be still my blessed babe, though cause thou hast to mourne: to mourne: whose bloud most innocent the cruell king hath sworne: hath sworne: the cruell king hath sworne: & lo, alas, behold, what slaughter hee doth make, hee doth make, ij. shedding the blod of, of infants all, sweet saui╌our for thy sake. for thy sake. A king is borne, they say, which king this
king would kill, wold kill, oh woe, woe, oh woe, woe, oh woe, & woeful heauy day, whē wretches haue their will. haue their wil. whē wretches haue their will. ij. oh woe, woe, oh woe, woe, oh woe, & woeful heauie day, whē wretches haue their will. haue their will. when wretches haue their will. ij.

lg.l: Lulla, la lulla, lulla lullaby,
My sweet little Babie, what meanest thou to cry.
Three kings this King of kings to see, are come from farre,
To each vnknowen, with offerings great, by guiding of a Starre:
And shepherds heard the song, which Angells bright did sing,
Giuing all glory vnto God, for comming of this King,
Which must bee made away, king Herod would him kill,
Oh woe and wofull heauie day, when wretches haue their will.
Lulla la lulla, lulla, lullaby, my sweet, &c.
Loe, my little Babe, bee still, lament no more,
From furie shalt thou step aside, help haue wee still in store:
Wee heauenly warning haue, some other soyle to seeke,
From death must flie the Lord of life, as Lamb both myld & meeke:
Thus must my Babe obey the king that would him kill,
Oh woe, and wofull heauie day, when wretches haue their will.
Lulla, la lulla, lulla lullaby, my sweet, &c.
But thou shalt liue and raigne, as Sibilles haue foresayd,
As all the Prophets prophesie, whose mother yet a maide,
And perfect Virgin pure, with her brestes shall vpbreede,
Both God and man that all hath made, the Sonne of heauenly seede:
Whome caytiues none can traye, whome tyrants none can kill,
Oh ioy, and ioyfull happie day, when wretches want their will.

div.head: XXXIII. TENOR.
div.p: 〈♫〉 WHY do I vse my paper inck & pen, my &c. why do I vse my paper inck and pen, & call my wits to counsell what to say, such memories, ij. were made for mortal men, for mortall men, I speak of Saints whose names cannot decay, an Angels trump, an Angels trump, ij. were fitter for to soūd, to soūd, their glori╌ous death, ij. if such on earth were foūd. on earth were found. an Angels trump, ij. an Angels trūp, ij. were fitter for to soūd, to soūd, their glori╌ous death, ij. if such on earth were found. if such on earth were found. ij.

lg.l: That store of such were once on earth pursu'd,
the histories of auncient times record,
whose constancie great tyrants rage subdu'd,
through patiēt death professing Christ their lord
as his Apostles perfect witnesse beare,
with many more that blessed Martirs were.
Whose patience rare & most couragious minde,
with same renoum'd perpetuall shall endure,
by whose examples wee may rightly finde,
of holy lyfe and death a patterne pure:
that wee therefore their vertues may embrace,
pray wee to Christ to guide vs with his grace.

div.head: The funerall songs of that honorable Gent. Sir Phillip Sidney, Knight. XXXIIII. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉
COme to mee griefe for euer, for euer, Come to mee teares day & night, day and night, day and night, Come to mee plaint, come to mee plaint, ah helplesse, iust griefe heart teares, plaint wor╌thie. iust griefe, heart teares, plaint worthie. plaint wor╌thie. iust griefe, heart teares, plaint worthie, plaint worthie.

lg.l: Goe fro mee dread to die now,
Goe fro mee care to liue more,
Goe fro mee ioyes all on earth,
Sidney, O Sidney is dead.
Hee whom the Court adorned,
Hee whom the countrie courtis'd,
Hee who made happie his friends,
Hee that dyd good to all men.
Sidney the hope of land strange,
Sidney the floure of England,
Sidney the spirite heroic,
Sidney is dead O dead, dead,
Dead? no, no, but renomed,
With the anoynted oned,
Honor on earth at his feete,
Blisse euerlasting his seate.

div.head: XXXV. TENOR.
div.p:
〈♫〉 O O that, O that most rare brest, most rare brest christalline sinceer, O that most rare brest, christalline sinceer, through which like gold like gold, through which like gold, thy princely hart did shine, O sprite heroic, he╌roic, O sprite heroic, O va╌li╌ant worthie knight, O Sidney, ij. ij. O Sidney, prince of fame, prince of fame, & mens good will. and mens good will. O Sidney, O Sidney. prince of fame, & mens good will. ij. ij. For, for thee, both kings & princesses doe mourn, for thee, both kings & princesses, for thee both kings & princesses doe mourne, thy noble Tombe, noble Tombe, thy noble Tombe, three Cities
strange de╌sired, foes to the cause, the cause, foes to the cause, thy prowes did de╌fend, beewaile the day, that crost thy famous race. beewaile the day, the day, the day, that crost thy famous race. thy famous race. bewaile the day, ij. that crost thy fa╌mous race. thy famous race. The dolfull debt due to thy hearse, I pay, the dolefull debt due to thy hearse I pay, I pay, teares from the soule, that aye thy want shall moane, that aye, &c. & by my will my life it selfe would yeeld, my life &c. if heathen blame, he might, my faith distaine. O heauie time, ij. heauie time, hea╌uie time, O hea╌uie time, that my daies draw behind thee, thou dead doest liue, doest
liue, thou dead doest liue, thou dead doest liue, ij. thy friend here liuing, dieth. Thy friend heere liuing dieth, liuing dieth. O heauie time, heauie time, heauie time, O hea╌uie time, that my daies draw behind thee, thou dead doest liue, doest liue, thou dead doest liue ij. thy friend heere liuing, dieth. thy &c. thy friend heree liuing di╌eth. thy &c. heere liuing, dy╌eth.

div.p: BASSVS.

Psalmes, Sonets, & songs of sadnes and pietie, made into Musicke of fiue parts: whereof, some of them going abroad among diuers, in vntrue coppies, are heere truely corrected, and th'other being Songs very rare and newly composed, are heere published, for the recreation of all such as delight in Musicke: By William Byrd one of the Gent: of the Queenes Maiesties Royall Chappell.

figure.figDesc: deer surrounded by humans and plants
figure.p: CERVA ▪ CHARISSIMA ▪ ET GRATISSIMVS HINNVLVS ▪ PRO: 5

div.p: Printed at London by Thomas Este, dwelling in Aldersgate streete, ouer against the signe of the George.

div.head: ¶ Reasons briefely set downe by th'author, to perswade euery one to learne to sing.
div.p: FIrst, it is a knowledge easely taught, and quickly learned, where there is a good Master, and an apt Scholler.
2 The exercise of singing is delightfull to Nature, & good to preserue the health of Man.
3 It doth strengthen all parts of the brest, & doth open the pipes.
4 It is a singular good remedie for a stutting and stamering in the speech.
5 It is the best meanes to procure a perfect pronounciation, & to make a good Orator.

6 It is the onely way to know where Nature hath bestowed the benefit of a good voyce: which guift is so rare, as there is not one among a thousand, that hath it: and in many, that excellent guift is lost because they want art to expresse Nature.
7 There is not any Musicke of Instruments whatsoeuer, comparable to that which is made of the voyces of Men, where the voyces are good, and the same well sorted and ordered.
8 The better the voyce is, the meeter it is to honour and serue God there-with: and the voyce of man is chiefely to bee imployed to that ende.

lg.l: Since singing is so good a thing,
I wish all men would learne to sing.

div.head: ¶ TO THE RIGHT HOnorable Sir Christopher Hatton Knight, Lord Chancellor of England, William Byrd wisheth long life, and the same to bee most healthie and happie.
div.p: THE often desires of many my good friends, Right honorable, and the consideration of many vntrue incorrected coppies of diuers my songs spred abroade, haue beene the two causes, chiefly mouing my consent at length to put in Print the fruits of my small skill and labors in Musicke. Then the dutie, honor, and seruice due from mee vnto your Lordship, together with the remembrance of your iudgement and loue of that Art, did moue & imbolden mee to present this first printed worke of mine in English, to passe vnder your L. fauour & protection: vnworthie I confesse, the view or Patronage of so worthie a Personage. Yet remembring that small things sometime do great seruice, & that repose is best tasted by bodies forewearied: I hoped that (by this occasion) these poore songs of mine might happely yeeld some sweetnesse, repose, and recreation vnto your Lordships mind, after your dayly paines & cares taken in the high affaires of the Cōmon VVealth. Most humbly beseeching your Lordship, that if my boldnesse heerein bee faultie, my dutifull good will, and good meaning may excuse it: which if I may so fortunately perceiue, it shall incourage mee to suffer some other things of more depth and skill to follow these, which beeing not yet finished, are of diuers expected and desired. Incessantly beseeching our Lord to make your yeeres happie, and end blessed, I wish there were any thing in mee worthie of your Lordship to be commanded.

closer.signed: Most humblie your L. euer to commaund William Byrd.

div.head: ¶ The Epistle to the Reader.
div.p: BEnigne Reader, heere is offered vnto thy courteous acceptation, Musicke of sundrie sorts, and to content diuers humors. If thou bee disposed to pray, heere are Psalmes. If to bee merrie, heere are Sonets. If to lament for thy sins, heere are songs of sadnesse and Pietie. If thou delight in Musicke of great cōpasse, heere are diuers songs, which beeing originally made for Instruments to expresse the harmony, and one voyce to pronounce the dittie, are now framed in all parts for voyces to sing the same. If thou desire songs of smal compasse and fit for the reach of most voyces, heere are most in number of that sort. Whatsoeuer paines I haue taken heerein, I shall thinke to be well imployed, if the same bee well accepted, Musicke thereby the better loued, and the more exercised. In the expressing of these songs, either by voyces or Instruments, if there happen to bee any iarre or dissonance, blame not the Printer, who (I doe assure thee) through his great paines and diligence, doth heere deliuer to thee a perfect and true Coppie. If in the composition of these Songs, there bee any fault by mee committed, I desire the skilfull, eyther with courtesie to let the same bee concealed, or in friendly sort to bee thereof admonished: and at the next Impression he shall finde the error reformed: remembring alwaies, that it is more easie to finde a fault then to amend it. If thou finde any thing heere worthie of liking and commendation, giue praise vnto GOD, from whom (as from a most pure and plentifull fountaine) all good guiftes of Sciences dooe flow: whose name bee glorified for euer.

closer.signed: The most assured friend to all that loue or learne Musicke: William Byrd.
